newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: Four-day polio programme to silence Sri Lanka war.
newsitem.headline: Four-day polio programme to silence Sri Lanka war.

text.p: Sri Lanka's separatist guerrillas agreed on Wednesday to four days of ceasefire to help implement an island-wide polio immunisation programme.
The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) said in a statement that their leader, Velupillai Prabhakaran, had declared September 6-7 and October 11-12 to be "days of tranquility" for the programme.
Brita Ostberg, the United Nations Children's Emergency Fund (UNICEF) representative in Sri Lanka, said she had appealed to the LTTE and the military to stop fighting on those days.
"I asked them," Ostberg told Reuters. "Sri Lanka is trying to eradicate polio. To do that, those who vaccinate need access to children and the children need access to them."
Army officials were not immediately available for comment on the appeal, but government troops have responded favourably to such appeals in the past.

The rebels are fighting a 13-year-old war for an independent homeland for minority Tamils in the Indian Ocean island's north and east. The government says more than 50,000 people have been killed in the conflict.
Government forces were dug in near the northern town of Kilinochchi, where the rebels set up their base after the army ousted them from their Jaffna peninsula stronghold in April.
The rebels have kept up sporadic hit-and-run attacks since they overran a northeastern army camp in July, killing or capturing almost its entire garrison of 1,400 men.
